results.title: China: The Long March
results.creator_credit: Chris Hooke, Peter Butt and Independent Productions (AU)
results.brief_description: An Australian photographer takes a historic journey retracing the historic trail of the Long March, by which Mao Tse Tung led 100,000 Communist cadres, on foot, across China. Traversing rivers, forests, mountain ranges and wild steppes, the Long March was central to consolidating the Communist Party’s support from the Chinese peasantry. This video offers an excellent historic account of the history of the Long March, as well as offering a breathtaking visual exploration of China and its people.

results.title: China: Sichuan province
results.creator_credit: Shirley Sun and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description: Sichuan Province, located in central China, is the most populous of all China’s Provinces. This film follows the route of the Chang Jiang (Yangtze River) as it flows eastwards from the mountainous Qinghai-Tibet Plateau to the fertile Sichuan Basin. The video looks at rice and wheat cultivation, mealtimes in a rural household, a government station where farmers sell their produce, and a rural school. The video also examines the people, commerce and industry of Chongqing, Sichuan’s largest city.

results.title: Children and sports (TEFC)
results.brief_description: James Michener surveys the work of the young athlete, to discover how sports activities effect young children. He takes a close look at both individual and team sports, talks with parents, coaches, physicians, and today’s young superstars and weighs the pros and cons of winning verses learning.

results.title: Children who cheated the Nazis
results.creator_credit: Sue Read, Jim Goulding and Golden Reed Productions
results.brief_description: A documentary on the Kindertransport children of Hitler’s Germany and the German occupied countries of Austria and Czechoslovakia whose parents were faced with the decision to send their children away, mostly to Britain, as conditions for Jews in Germany and later elsewhere increasingly deteriorated. Collected with archival footage, discussion of the Kindertransport program and interviews with resistance members and families involved in the initiative this program contains the reflections of the now aged children themselves. They discuss how their families were effected when the Nazis came to power and what led them to be sent from all that was familiar to new lives in a country with a strange language and an unknown culture. Their moving stories are detailed with a view to their own lives and how the experience effected them as well as what happened to the families they had to leave behind. Includes interviews with Lord Attenborough and actor Warren Mitchell, whose families took in Kindertransport children.

results.title: Children of two countries. Parts I and II
results.creator_credit: Terry Ohlsson, Huang Guang, China Film Co-operation, J C Williamson Film Management and Kingcroft Productions
results.brief_description: This two-part series is about a cultural exchange between China and Australia and sixteen young primary school children between the ages of 9 to 11, eight Chinese students from different cities and rural areas of China and eight Australian students from various schools and States in Australia. Part I: The Middle Kingdom - We follow the Australian children through the fascinating land of China, beginning with their introduction to a Chinese primary school in Canton, where differences of language and culture are soon overcome. Their travels take them on a boat trip down the Li River, to the Children’s Palace in Shanghai, the Great Wall, to see the giant pandas at Beijing, Tien An Men Square, the Great Hall of the People, and finally, to meet Madame Kang Kequing, Vice Chairman of China. Part II: The Lucky Country - Following the Australian children’s visit to China, eight Chinese children make the long journey to Australia, a vast island continent of extremes and so different to their own country. The children are accompanied by three of the young Australians who went to China. They meet the then Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, row a surf boat, watch a parade of wild penguins, visit an outback sheep station, take part in a lesson by radio in the famous “School of the Air” and sample life in Sydney and Melbourne. Narrated by Peter Sumner.

results.title: Children of the long-beaked bird
results.creator_credit: Amanda K. Fox, Burton K. Fox, John Hoskyns-Abrahall, Peter F. Davis, Bullfrog Films and Sveriges television
results.brief_description: The lifestyle of American Crow Indians living on reservations and preserving their traditions. In particular, the film follows the daily activities of Dominic Old Elk, the great-grandson of George Armstrong, Custer’s Indian scout. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Children of fire
results.creator_credit: Mai Masri, Fatima Masri, George Khleifi, BBC-TV and M T C
results.brief_description: Nablus, situated in the Israeli Occupied West Bank and home to 120,000 exiled Palestinians is also the home of filmmaker Mai Masri. It is 9 September 1989 and fourteen years since Mai has been in Nablus when she returns to her hometown to document Palestinian life since the beginning of the Intifada. Mai very quickly finds out that Nablus is not the peaceful town where she grew up - it is instead a place of violence, death, fear and tension, where young children have been robbed of their innocence and often their lives. The Palestinians in Nablus are constantly under survellience the Israeli Army which only serves to heighten the frustration and determination of the younger generation to fight for their freedom and confront the occupiers head-on, albeit with weapons of stones. Children as young as five are aware of their situation as exiles and from the ages of six and seven, many will become street-fighters, their games often replicating real life. Through these children’s personal stories and the violent images in their childish paintings, as well as some rather disturbing film footage of the Israeli soldiers in action, Mai Masri presents an uncompromising and courageous portrayal of Nablus and the children of the Intifada. (Awards: Cairo Television Festival 1995; Feminin Pluriel Festival) In English and Arabic with English subtitles.

results.title: High noon in Jakarta
results.creator_credit: Christine Olsen, Curtis Levy, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Olsen Levy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big picture”.
A look at the life of Abdurrahman Wahid, the first democratically elected President of Indonesia and the many challenges he faces in governing this highly fragmented society. Shows the pressure Wahid faces from the Army, which is reluctant to hand over powers it gained under the 30 years of General Soeharto’s dictatorship. Follows Wahid on a foreign trip while back in Indonesia General Wiranto, the Indonesian military leader, has been accused of human rights abuses against the East Timorese people. An interesting and insightful documentary of President Wahid, his family, his Islamic beliefs and philosophy, and his political diplomacy with foreign leaders and the international media. Includes images of some personal and upfront moments in Wahid’s daily rituals.

results.title: Child soldiers [Widescreen] (D)
results.creator_credit: Alan Lindsay, Andrew Ogilvie, ABC-TV (Australia), Electric Pictures (Aust), OPB and ScreenWest
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big picture”.
This is an extremely disturbing documentary on the use and abuse of children as young as 10 years old being recruited as child soldiers by various means - voluntary or involuntary - through abduction, intimidation, coercion, or exploitation of a child’s social circumstances. More than thirty nations globally participate in this barbaric and inhumane practice involving over 300,000 children (conservative estimate by the United Nations) who are brutalised, drugged, brainwashed, and indoctrinated to kill and commit atrocities in civil wars and armed conflict. From Southern Sudan to Uganda, Burma, Columbia and Sierra Leone we are confronted with some of these young soldiers (girls as well as boys) and their horrific accounts of life as a child soldier. Many tell of their dangerous attempts at escape, returning home, only to be kidnapped again and again. However even more distressing is the enormous challenge these ex child soldiers have to face in overcoming the abuse and trauma which they have suffered, both physically and psychologically. Many of them end up homeless, too frightened to return home. And it is not only third world countries who recruit underage soldiers. The US recruit 17 year olds and Great Britain has no hesitation in sending 16 year olds off to war. Both the United Nations and the International Criminal Court are trying to resolve this human crisis but it is going to be a long hard struggle and in the meantime tragically, hundreds of thousands of young children worldwide are pawns in an adult game of violence and conflict. Narrated by Anthony LaPaglia. NOTE: CONTAINS MANY VISUALLY DISTURBING IMAGES.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alan Lindsay, Andrew Ogilvie, ABC-TV (Australia), Electric Pictures (Aust), OPB and ScreenWest

Episode of Series “Big picture”.
This is an extremely disturbing documentary on the use and abuse of children as young as 10 years old being recruited as child soldiers by various means - voluntary or involuntary - through abduction, intimidation, coercion, or exploitation of a child’s social circumstances. More than thirty nations globally participate in this barbaric and inhumane practice involving over 300,000 children (conservative estimate by the United Nations) who are brutalised, drugged, brainwashed, and indoctrinated to kill and commit atrocities in civil wars and armed conflict. From Southern Sudan to Uganda, Burma, Columbia and Sierra Leone we are confronted with some of these young soldiers (girls as well as boys) and their horrific accounts of life as a child soldier. Many tell of their dangerous attempts at escape, returning home, only to be kidnapped again and again. However even more distressing is the enormous challenge these ex child soldiers have to face in overcoming the abuse and trauma which they have suffered, both physically and psychologically. Many of them end up homeless, too frightened to return home. And it is not only third world countries who recruit underage soldiers. The US recruit 17 year olds and Great Britain has no hesitation in sending 16 year olds off to war. Both the United Nations and the International Criminal Court are trying to resolve this human crisis but it is going to be a long hard struggle and in the meantime tragically, hundreds of thousands of young children worldwide are pawns in an adult game of violence and conflict. Narrated by Anthony LaPaglia. NOTE: CONTAINS MANY VISUALLY DISTURBING IMAGES.
